edu.cnm.deepdive.videopoker.model

Class Converter

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.cnm.deepdive.videopoker.model.Converter

  • public class Converter
extends Object
    This class exists to convert a String sequence into the rules for a poker hand. The parseRuleSequence method handles the conversion and tests against a given hand.

    • Method Detail

      • parseRuleSequence

        public boolean parseRuleSequence(String ruleSequence,
                                 Stack<Card> playerHand)
        This method checks if provided hand matches a provided sequence of patterns.
        Parameters:
        ruleSequence - A string to represent the rules of a poker hand. It should be a sequence of patterns separated by a semicolon. If multiple patterns are provided the hand will only return true if it matches all of the patterns. Cards are removed upon a match so care must be taken to put the more complex patterns first, for example, a three of a kind will evaluate as a pair if the pattern is run first. Within each sequence, pattern rules are separated by commas. Each rule contains two characters, the first character representing the rank of the hand and the second character representing the suit. Hands are sorted by rank upon evaluation, so there is limited flexibility with suit rules. Currently only a flush is supported. The rules for ranks are as follows:
        • * - wildcard, any pattern matches.
        • = - pattern matches if this element matches the previous element in the pattern.
        • + - pattern rank is one higher than the previous element in the pattern.
        • F - pattern rank is a face card - an Ace or a card higher than rank 11 (Jack)
        • Any other character is assumed to be a literal.
          Warning! If it is not a literal that corresponds to a rank ("A, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, T, J, Q, K") it will likely throw an exception.
        playerHand - The hand of cards to be evaluated against the ruleSequence.
        Returns:
        true if the hand matches the sequence, false if there is a failure on any of the patterns.
